newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech battle on drug adverts highlights hot debate.
newsitem.headline: Czech battle on drug adverts highlights hot debate.

text.p: Czech broadcasters and legislators are battling over whether non-prescription medicine can be advertised on television in a court case that highlights a fierce debate over how advertising should be regulated.
"It's a complicated issue. It's a jungle," Vladimir Zelezny, director general of TV NOVA, a private Czech television network, told an advertising conference on Wednesday.

Zelezny, whose network is one of two which has sought a court ruling on whether over-the-counter drugs can be advertised on television, said the confusion over the law is symptomatic of the regulatory problems plaguing the Czech advertising industry.

Drug advertising is regulated by the Czech Ministry of Health Care in a country that is trying to adopt Western models of self-regulation for advertising while still maintaining a role for the law in certain cases.

Like other current advertising regulation in the Czech Republic, the ban on drug advertising was introduced after the fall of communism in 1989 heralded a new era in free market economics. But without a tradition of capitalism and advertising, legislators and advertisers have struggled to find the right blend of freedom and oversight.

The court case on advertising over-the counter drugs has been pending for seven months, following a ruling by the Ministry of Health Care that the current legislation prohibits advertising drugs on television.
But deputy health minister Alex Dvoulety and Jan Kasal, vice president of the Czech House of Representatives, admitted the law is ambiguous.
"My personal view is OTC advertisement is is legal," Dvoulety said. "The ministry thinks otherwise."
"I have to agree ... that the law is not very clear," said Kasal. But he cautioned that one has to understand the climate in which the law was introduced.

Zelezny argued that much of the problem lies with legislators learning to understand the workings of a free press -- one that should not be subject to the kind of censorship that the communist regime imposed on what it termed the information media..
"There are problems with the Ministry of Health Care, because the Ministry of Health Care has no experience with TV," he said.
"I hope in the future we'll be able to learn from the European countries," he added.
